I would be glad to help. Here are some examples of author exhibitions or programs that have been hosted at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the past:

1. David Hockney: A Retrospective (2018): This exhibition marked the first major retrospective of David Hockney's work in over 30 years. The exhibition included over 400 works, including paintings, photographs, and installations. It was accompanied by a fully illustrated catalog with essays from leading art historians and an exhibition-related program featuring talks, tours, and workshops.

2. Michelangelo: Divine Draftsman and Designer (2017): This exhibition brought together over 150 works of Michelangelo, including his drawings, sculptures, and architectural models. The exhibition catalog featured essays and insights from art historians and scholars, and the accompanying program included talks, tours, and workshops.

3. Views and Re-Views: Soviet Political Posters and Cartoons (2012): This exhibition explored the role of political propaganda in the Soviet Union through a display of over 50 posters and cartoons. The exhibition catalog included an essay by the curator, and the program featured talks and a panel discussion on the topic.

4. Thomas Cole's Journey: Atlantic Crossings (2018): This exhibition traced the journey of Thomas Cole, the founder of the Hudson River School of Painting, and his influence on American landscape painting. The exhibition was accompanied by a catalog with essays from leading art historians and an exhibition-related program featuring talks, tours, and workshops.

5. Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting (2017): This exhibition explored the works of Johannes Vermeer and other Dutch genre painters. The exhibition included over 60 works from museums and private collections around the world, and the accompanying catalog featured essays from leading art historians. The program included talks, tours, and workshops.

These author exhibitions or programs are just a few examples of the range of exhibitions and programs that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has hosted in the past. It demonstrates that the museum’s programming span across various themes, genres, and periods, covering both classical and contemporary works.
